title: Penalty rates blame-game: Coalition and Labor pin Sunday pay cut on each other
text:

NSW Energy and Utilities Minister Don Harwin has requested the public make restrictions to their power usage between peak times to prevent potential rolling blackouts, despite claiming we have a power surplus. More videos Penalty rates: leaders allocate blame 
Opposition Leader Bill Shorten and Minister for Employment Michaelia Cash trade barbs on who is responsible for the penalty rate change announced Thursday. (Vision courtesy ABC News 24) 
Employment Minister Michaelia Cash said Opposition Leader Bill Shorten could not "escape responsibility for the outcome" because he instigated the review as Workplace Relations Minister in the Gillard Government. 
"Any suggestion by Bill Shorten and the Labor Party that they do not accept this decision is highly hypocritical," she said. SHARE Share on Twitter TWEET Link Existing fast-food and retail industry workers may lose Sunday penalties but the industry believes more jobs will be created by the Fair Work Commission ruling. Photo: Marina Neil 
"Bill Shorten needs to explain why he instigated a wide-ranging review of penalty rates if he does not support a change in penalty rates. Bill Shorten is responsible for establishing the framework that has led to today's decision. He cannot now escape responsibility for the outcome of this process." 
Mr Shorten retaliated, claiming Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull would be "pleased", having delivered for the business community. Advertisement 
He said it was the Turnbull Government that called in the Productivity Commission to review penalty rates and its findings underpinned Thursday's decision. 
"He has campaigned for this outcome for many years, whereas Labor was the only political party who submitted a case against the cutting of penalty rates," Mr Shorten said. 
"What this will do is this will reallocate wages of working people in this country to business profits. This is not going to lead to a million people being employed. What this is going to do is it means for a shop assistant who currently works for 10 hours on a Sunday, they will have to work for 13.5 hours just to get the same money that they used to get. This won't lead to greater employment, it will lead to greater hardship." 
While business groups welcomed the streamlining of weekend rates, unions reacted with anger and dismay, calling on Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull to intervene to prevent people losing pay. 
ACTU president Ged Kearney said without a "severe" government intervention, a class of "working poor" would be created in Australia. 
"We are talking about people who don't earn a fortune. The retail industry made a very healthy operating profit last year. They can afford to pay people decently," she said. 
"Malcolm Turnbull, as Prime Minister of this country, unless he acts immediately, will forever be remembered as the Prime Minister who oversaw an attack on the wages of the lowest-paid people in our economy." 
Gerard Dwyer, national secretary of the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees' Association, known as the "shoppies", said retail and fast-food workers would lose $1 billion a year. 
Conservative Liberal backbencher Eric Abetz, who was employment minister under Tony Abbott, welcomed the decision, saying the Commission had been "mugged by the realities" its previous determination not to adjust penalty rates has "cost jobs and investment in the hospitality, retail and tourism sectors". 
Sydney Liberal Jason Falinski, a member of the moderate faction, tweeted that the decision was "good news for jobs and consumers - more jobs, more choice". 
Greens industrial relations spokesman Adam Bandt said the party would attempt to use Parliament to avert the loss of Sunday rates, calling on Labor and the crossbenchers to unite on the issue. 
"This cut in penalty rates is a cut in people's wages and it will hit young people especially hard. At a time when we are experiencing record-low wages growth, more people than ever depend on penalty rates to pay rent and bills," he said. 
"Coffees won't get any cheaper on Sundays but young people will find it harder to pay the rent." 
The Australian Industry Group said many young people, particularly students, prefer to work on weekends and nights and traditional work hours have little relevance to industries like fast-food. 
"In the fast-food industry, weekends and evenings are peak times. Regular business hours have little relevance to businesses in the fast-food industry and, therefore, penalty rates that were designed many decades ago around regular business hours need to be reset," said Ai Group chief executive Innes Willox. 
"In the decision, the Commission has recognised that existing Sunday penalty rates in the fast-food industry are not fair for employers and no longer relevant."
